page.title: 04Landscape and Buildings
page.content: Saxilby originally developed along the High Street, up Church Road and down Mill Lane forming a reversed D shape, rising gently to the ancient parish church of St Botolph. The rebuilt tower (1907) and 6 bells abut a fine clerestoried nave, double chancel of the perpendicular style (c.1350 - 1500) and a north aisle dating back to early Norman (c.1100). From the tower one can see north east across fields to Broxholme, north west to the light industrial units on Church Lane ( making staircases, metal spares and poultry grit ) and south across the village to the Lincoln to Sheffield railway line, still in use, as are the platforms, but the once fine station building incorporating the station master's house (c.1849) and later 19th century additions, stands partly empty and in decay.
